Bournonville, G. Mabilon, G. Martino Institut Francais du Petrole, 1-4 Av. de Bois Preau, 92506 Rueil-Malmaison Cedex (France) J. P. Candy and J.-M. Basset Institut de Recherches sur la Catalyse, Conventionne avec l'Universite Claude Bernard, 2 av. A. Einstein, 69626 Villeurbanne Cedex (France) (Received August 23, 1990; revised March 14, 1991) Abstract Bimetallic catalysts Rh-Sn, Ni-Sn and Ru-Sn, prepared via an organometallic route, are very selective for the hydrogenolysis of ethyl acetate to ethanol. This generation of catalysts, requires lower temperatures and lower pressures than the traditional copper chromites and constitutes an elegant method for the hydrogenolysis of (fatty) esters into (fatty) alcohols, which are important raw materials derived from natural resources. The objective of this work was to identify, via kinetic experiments, the primary products of the reaction in order to propose a mechanistic explanation for the selective hydrogenation of ethyl acetate to ethanol. Changing the Sn/Rh ratio drastically modifies both the activity and the selectivity of the catalysts: In the range 0 < Sn/Rh < 0.2, both the activity and the selectivity for hydrogenolysis to CO and CH, decrease. On the other hand, for Sri/ Rh ratios higher than ca. 0.2, both the activity and the selectivity for the ethanol formation increase almost linearly with the tin content while the rates of alkane and CO formation remain constant and very low. At Sn/Rh=1.7, kinetic studies indicate that ethanol, acetaldehyde and ethane are the primary products, whereas CO and CH4 are secondary products. The rate low, which is of the form: r=k(I'HZ) .5KEAPEA1 +KEAPEn+KEPE) is totally different from that observed on pure rhodium. These kinetic data, associated with previous physical observations leading to the concept of 'site isolation' of rhodium atoms in a matrix of tin atoms, lead to the proposal of a reaction mechanism involving a single rhodium atom. Introduction Hydrogenolysis of esters is difficult to achieve, both in homogeneous [ 1-5 ] and heterogeneous catalysis [ 6-18 ]. High temperatures and high 0304-5102/91/$3.50 1991- Elsevier Sequoia, Lausanne 284 pressures are required and it is rarely a selective reaction. In heterogeneous catalysis, depending on the nature of the substituents of the ester and depending on the catalyst, the product can be an alcohol, an acid or a hydrocarbon [7, 10]. The R-C(O)-/-O-R' bond in an ester is the most easily cleavable by hydrogen; which leads selectively to two alcohols R-CHZOH and R'-OH. So far, the catalysts which have been most commonly used for such reactions are copper chromites stabilized byvarious substituents [ 11-15]. Raney copper or zinc oxide-chromium oxide have also been used [ 16-18 ] . However, the drastic conditions required by these catalysts lead to hydrogenolysis of the alcohol itself. Recently it has been found that bimetallic catalysts Rh-Sn, Ni-Sn and Ru-Sn, prepared via an organometallic route, can be very selective for hydrogenolysis of ethyl acetate to ethanol [ 19-23 ]. This generation of bimetallic catalysts requires lower temperatures and lower pressures than the traditional copper chromites and constitutes an elegant method for the hydrogenolysis of (fatty) esters into (fatty) alcohols which are important raw materials derived from natural resources. Since, in this reaction, high selectivities can be achieved with the bimetallic Rh-Sn catalysts prepared via the organometallic route, it was of interest to study the mechanism of the reaction by identification of the primary products and determination of the kinetic law. The high selectivity of the reaction may be explained by a molecular approach, considering that the active sites are a combination of both the incoming molecules and the surface metal atom(s). The objective of this paper is therefore to propose a mechanistic explanation for the selective hydrogenolysis of ethyl acetate with these bimetallic catalysts, based on kinetic studies as well as previous studies which were primarily focussed on catalyst characterization. Experimental The silica support (small pellets, 1 mm in diameter, surface area 250 m2 g-') was purchased from Shell. Liquids reagents had a purity higher than 99.9%. Hydrogen was deoxygenated by flowing through a column filled with platinum catalyst and then dried over a 4A molecular sieve. Electron microscopy studies were performed with JEOL 120X (CTEM) and VG HB5 (STEM) instruments. Chemisorption of CO and Hz were measured using a conventional volumetric apparatus (Bell and Howell pressure gauge). Microprobe measurements were performed with a Microbeam. The pellets were embedded in an epoxy resin, the resulting samples were cut using a diamond saw and subsequently polished. Rhodium was grafted to silica by cationic exchange between [RhCI(NH3)5]2+ ions and the surface ~Si-O-NH4+ groups at pH 10 [24]. The !~-Si-O-NH,+ groups were obtained by exchange between 'Si-O-H+ groups and NH4+ ions in ammonia solution. [RhCI(NH3)5](OH)Z was obtained 285 by contacting [RhCl(NH3)51C12 with an anionic exchange resin (IRA 400) in aqueous solution. The surface complex obtained was decomposed by calcination at 570 K in flowing dry air and then reduced in flowing hydrogen at 570 K to give catalyst A. This catalyst contained 1 wt% of rhodium. A could be transformed into B by treatment with dry oxygen at 300 K for 1 h. The particle size of B was in the range of 1.0-1.5 run as determined by electron microscopy. Adsorption of a given amount of Sn(n-C4H9)4 in n-heptane on B was carried out at 370 K for 24 h [22-231. Various concentrations of Sn(nC4H9)4 at this stage could control the final Sn%Rh ratio, at least for Sn/Rh ratios lower than 1.7. After removal of the solvent, the solid was loaded into the catalytic reactor and reduced under flowing hydrogen (6 mol h-' g-') at increasing temperatures (1 h at 373, 523 and 723 K, respectively). Hydrogenation of ethyl acetate was carried out in a conventional fixedbed flow reactor at 500-600 K under 0.1 to 5 MPa of hydrogen and 0-0.5 MPa of ethyl acetate [221. The contact time was varied between 2.2 and 40 h. Activity (r) can be defined as the number of moles of ethyl acetate transformed per gram of catalyst per hour. Selectivity (Si) can be defined as the ratio of the carbon weight in product i to the total carbon weight in all the products. The following procedure was used to carry out kinetic experiments: a given quantity of catalyst was loaded in the reactor and reduced under a stream of hydrogen (6 mol h-' g-') at increasing temperatures (1 h at 373, 523 and 723 K). After cooling the reactor to the desired temperature, the total pressure and the ethyl acetate/hydrogen molecular ratio were adjusted to the chosen values. After 2 h, the effluents were analysed by gas chromatography (Girdel 300 chromatograph), using a column with 13X molecular sieve for carbon monoxide and a capillary column (CP-SIL-5) for the other products. Water was measured by a Mitsubishi hydrometer. Tetra-n-butyltin does not react significantly with the silica support, but reacts slowly at 370 K with the oxidized rhodium surface. After treatment at 723 K under flowing hydrogen, all the butyl groups from the grafted organotin are eliminated, which suggests formation of a bimetallic particle. Kinetic conditions With silica-supported rhodium and rhodium-tin catalysts, ethyl acetate is converted into ethanol, ethane, methane, CO, water, acetaldehyde and diethyl ether. The ethyl acetate conversion is proportional to the residence time up to ca. 10% conversion. This linear relationship is observed whether the catalyst is used in pellet form (1 mm diameter) or is crushed into a powder. At this level of conversion, the reactor works in a differential regime. Influence of tin content When the tin content increases, there are drastic changes in the overall rate of reaction as well as in the selectivity (Fig. 3). On increasing the Sn/ Rh ratio from 0 to 0.2, the rates of ethanol, alkanes and CO formation decrease sharply. Above 0.2 Sn/Rh, the rates of allcane and CO formation remain constant, whereas that of ethanol formation increases strongly. These results correspond to a selectivity toward ethanol higher than 90% for a Sn/ Rh ratio higher than 0.7 (Fig. 3 and Table 2). Discussion Addition of tin via the organometallic route to a classical Rh/Si02 catalyst leads to drastic changes in the product distribution observed in the hydrogenolysis of ethyl acetate. The new catalyst exhibits a very high chemoselectivity in the hydrogenation of ethyl acetate to ethanol. As the ratio Sn/ Rh increases from 0 to 0.2, the conversion of ethyl acetate decreases sharply. 291 Above a Sn/Rh ratio of 0.2, both the conversion of ethyl acetate and the selectivity for ethanol increase with tin content, to reach values higher than 95% for a Sn/Rh ratio higher than unity. Whereas Rh/Si02 gives CHq, CZHg, CO and CO2, corresponding to a completely unselective C-C or C-O bond cleavage, Rh-Sn/Si0z with Sn/Rh= 1.7 exhibits a very high chemoselectivity for the C(O)-O bond cleavage of the ester group. Firstly, at low Sn/Rh ratios (Sn/Rh < 0.2), the sharp decrease in the rate of ethanol, alkane and CO formation with increasing tin content, clearly indicates that tin has a poisoning effect on the Rh for the ethyl acetate conversion. Above a Sn/Rh ratio of 0.2, the rate of ethanol formation increases almost linearly with tin content, suggesting the appearance of a new catalytic material, completely different from rhodium. This hypothesis is confirmed by the constant value of the apparent activation energy (EJ for ethyl acetate conversion, which is much lower (55 KJ mol-') than that observed with the monometallic Rh/Si02 catalyst (90 KJ mol-1). The reaction mechanism must be very different with Rb/Si02 and Rh-Sn/Si02 (0.2 < Sn/Rh < 1.7). In the range 0 < Sn/Rh < 0.2, the role of tin is expected to decrease the size of the `ensembles' of Rh atoms. Consequently, the `demanding' reactions are almost eliminated as demonstrated for other bimetallic catalysts [27, 28]. In our case, the `demanding' reactions would be the hydrogenolysis of the ethyl acetate to CO, CZHs and CHQ. For tin contents higher than 0.2 Sn/Rh, the rate of ethanol formation increases almost linearly with tin content, while the rate of alkane + CO formation remains constant and very low. It is clear that, in this range of tin content, a simple geometric `ensemble' effect cannot explain the results. A new catalytic material, presumably an alloy RhxSn,, the concentration of which increases with increasing Sn content, is responsible for the high activity and the high selectivity. The extremely high selectivity which is observed with the Rh-Sn alloy must certainly reflect the presence of a unique mechanism occurring on this bimetallic phase. Spectroscopic data (XPS, TEM) confirm that rhodium and tin are in the zero-valent state [26]. It is probably more important to note that in the bimetallic phase the amount of adsorbed CO has significantly decreased, but simultaneously the bridging COs have almost completely disappeared. Consequently the surface can be best `represented' by isolated rhodium atoms surrounded by tin atoms. The fact that a few bridging carbonyls are still observed suggests that a few pairs of rhodium atoms are still present in close vicinity. The presence of bridging CO in a zero-valent rhodium particle suggests that the rhodium-rhodium interatomic distance does not exceed 0.31 nm (see for example the interatomic distance of rhodium clusters in the complexes of Chini et al. [29]). The proposal of a reaction mechanism must take into account the identification of the primary products and the kinetic law, as well as the poisoning experiments which may confirm the nature of the `active site'. Regarding the primary products, the selectivity versus conversion curves clearly indicate that ethanol and acetaldehyde are primary products. Consequently, the mechanism which is proposed should lead only to these two 292 molecules. The fact that acetaldehyde is observed in smaller amounts than ethanol suggests that the former is quickly hydrogenated to ethanol. Poisoning experiments by CO and ethanol suggest that the rhodium atoms are the active sites. Since the highest selectivity is observed with the Sn/Rh ratio which gives rise to the smallest amount of bridging CO, it is logical to conclude that the active sites are the isolated rhodium atoms. The kinetic equation does not seem to imply a competition between ethyl acetate and hydrogen. This phenomenon may be correlated with the half-order in hydrogen, which suggests a `formal' addition of HZ on two `adjacent' rhodium atoms. We have seen previously that the number of these `adjacent' rhodium atoms is relatively small. Once the oxidative addition of HZ has occurred, the facile process of H migration on the bimetallic particle seems a reasonable hypothesis. The proposal of a mechanism for ethyl acetate hydrogenation, although it is always speculative by nature, can be formulated in the following way: coordination of the ethyl acetate to isolated rhodium atom should occur via the 7r-electron system of the molecule. The highest electron density must be on the oxygen atom of the carbonyls, which may interact with the lowest unoccupied orbitals (of the s or d band) at the rhodium atom. The transfer of the first hydrogen atom to the carbon atom will lead to the hemiacetal (II), according to the Adkins model [30). It is possible that tin atoms participate in the complexation of the acetaldehyde, but at this moment we have no evidence in favor of this hypothesis. This mechanism takes into account the major observations which were made regarding the nature of the `active' site, kinetic laws and product distribution (the only remaining uncertainty concerns the role of tin in the adsorption process of the molecule): -isolated rhodium atoms seem to be the active site for the reaction; -adjacent rhodium atoms seem to be necessary for hydrogen dissociation; -ethanol and acetaldehyde are primary products; 293 - CO and ethanol poison the reaction due to their adsorption on `isolated' rhodium atoms; -apparent activation energies for Rh-Sn are totally different from those observed for rhodium alone. Conclusion Controlled surface reaction of tetra-n-butyltin with a silica-supported rhodium catalyst leads to a new bimetallic phase which is more active and more selective than the monometallic starting material toward alcohol formation from ethyl acetate. Kinetic studies of the reaction allows us to propose a mechanism in which the limiting step is the first addition of an adsorbed hydrogen atom to the carbon atom of the carboxyl group. The adsorbed hemiacetal intermediate then reacts quickly with adsorbed hydrogen atoms to give acetaldehyde and an adsorbed ethoxy group, which are rapidly hydrogenated to ethanol. References 1 U. This generation of catalysts, requires lower temperatures and lower pressures than the traditional copper chromites and constitutes an elegant method for the hydrogenolysis of (fatty) esters into (fatty) alcohols, which are important raw materials derived from natural resources. The objective of this work was to identify, via kinetic experiments, the primary products of the reaction in order to propose a mechanistic explanation for the selective hydrogenation of ethyl acetate to ethanol. Changing the Sn/Rh ratio drastically modifies both the activity and the selectivity of the catalysts: In the range 0 < Sn/Rh < 0.2, both the activity and the selectivity for hydrogenolysis to CO and CH4 decrease. On the other hand, for Sn/Rh ratios higher than ca. 0.2, both the activity and the selectivity for the ethanol formation increase almost linearly with the tin content while the rates of alkane and CO formation remain constant and very low. At Sn/Rh = 1.7, kinetic studies indicate that ethanol, acetaldehyde and ethane are the primary products, whereas CO and CH4 are secondary products. The rate low, which is of the form: r = k(P H2)0.5 K EA P EA/(1 + K EA P EA + K E P E) is totally different from that observed on pure rhodium. These kinetic data, associated with previous physical observations leading to the concept of ‘site isolation’ of rhodium atoms in a matrix of tin atoms, lead to the proposal of a reaction mechanism involving a single rhodium atom.
